Award.AwardTitle: Using Single-Cell Data to Decipher Mechanisms of NF-kB-chromatin-mediated HIV Transcriptional Regulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264246
Miller-Jensen, Kathryn

Genetically identical cells can display significant phenotypic heterogeneity as a result of random fluctuations (noise) in gene expression, which is modulated by transcription factor binding and chromatin modifications at each gene promoter. The interaction of chromatin and transcription factors is especially evident among mammalian retroviruses, such as the human immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV), which integrate semi-randomly into the genome of their host's DNA and depend on host regulatory factors to initiate viral gene expression and complete replication. In the case of HIV, noisy viral gene expression results in transcriptional delays that may be a precursor for latent infections. Latent HIV currently prevents complete eradication of the virus in a patient, and reversing viral latency via activation of the latent HIV reservoir is a promising therapeutic strategy. However, an incomplete understanding of the complex mechanisms underlying chromatin- and transcription factor-mediated regulation of HIV hinders progress. To address this knowledge gap, the proposed project integrates experimental and computational approaches to study how the canonical transcription factor NF-kB and the local chromatin environment at the viral integration site together regulate activation of the latent HIV LTR promoter.

The inability to target and purge latent (i.e., silent) HIV-infected cells is currently the biggest obstacle to a cure, and this proposal seeks to address this significant public health problem. By integrating single-cell experiments and computational modeling, this research will improve understanding of how protein-DNA interactions called chromatin regulate HIV-1 transcription, and will further progress towards eradication of the latent viral reservoir. This work may also advance knowledge of mechanisms of chromatin-mediated transcriptional regulation more broadly, with the potential to impact immunology, development, and cancer. In addition, two educational initiatives are proposed to broaden participation of under-represented minority engineering students in interdisciplinary research through summer research fellowships; and to contribute to transformative teaching approaches at the interface of the biological and physical sciences through design of a new discussion session for an interdisciplinary graduate course.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An overarching goal of biological engineering research is to understand the biochemical network interactions inside cells that allow them to respond specifically to environmental cues. A quantitative understanding of these network interactions is important to enable strategic targeting of the interactions for therapeutic purposes. One general mechanism to alter how genes respond to biochemical signals–and thus increase signal specificity–is to alter chromatin, the collective term for the proteins that regulate access to the genes in different genomic locations. However, it is often difficult to study how chromatin changes signal-gene interactions for the same gene promoter. In this project, we used the natural variability in the genomic integration locations of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) promoter to study how chromatin changes gene expression regulated by the signaling molecule nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-κB). To accomplish this work, we invented a simple microfluidic device to facilitate long-term imaging of single suspension cells. By combining single-cell imaging experiments, quantitative analysis, and molecular biology, we showed how chromatin causes the same input NF-κB signal to direct gene expression using different mechanisms of transcription. We showed that different mechanisms of NF-κB “signal decoding” (i.e., the mechanisms by which signals at the promoter are converted to gene expression) can produce similar mean numbers of transcripts in the short term but ultimately sustain different levels of gene expression once the signal is removed. This result is significant because it suggests a new mechanism for how signals are integrated at the promoter over time to enable specific gene expression. We also showed how these different mechanisms of signal decoding, which are determined by the initial chromatin environment, lead to specific responses to repeated environmental stimulations.

The intellectual merit of this research was to use HIV as a model gene promoter to enable experiments across quantitatively different chromatin environments in order to improve our understanding about how NF-κB controls transcriptional activation. Moreover, we demonstrated new ways to combine single-cell experiments with molecular biology approaches to discover biological mechanisms of biochemical network “signal decoding” that can now be tested for endogenous promoters. Our work also motivates a new way to think about the clinically important problem of how to activate and clear latent HIV infections, which are also regulated by chromatin, from patients.

The broader impact of this research was to increase the participation of undergraduate and graduate students at the interface between engineering and biology. To accomplish this goal, we hosted three undergraduate summer research interns from other universities in our lab, including two from under-represented minority groups. In addition, developed a new class module for a core course in the Integrated Graduate Program in Physical and Engineering Biology at Yale University.
